Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of the anaphase-promoting complex by pseudosubstrate inhibition

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Project Description. The process of cell division, by which a single parent cell gives rise to two identical daughter cells, is amazingly complex. At its core are the duplication of the cell's entire genome and the accurate distribution of one intact copy of the genome to each of the two daughter cells. Remarkably, almost all non-bacterial species use the same basic machinery and regulatory controls to achieve cell division. How the complex steps involved in cell division are regulated is still only partially understood. In this project, budding yeast will be used as a simple model system to study one essential component of cell division control, regulated protein destruction. The project aims to understand how a key enzyme responsible for protein destruction during cell division is activated and inactivated, and the mechanism by which it specifically recognizes its targets. By using the yeast model system, a broad array of molecular techniques spanning the fields of cell biology, genetics, biochemistry, and biophysics will be applied to achieve the aims. The project will help advance the general understanding of molecular mechanisms of 1) cell division control, and 2) regulated protein destruction.

Broader Impact. The research project is associated with graduate and undergraduate programs in biochemistry. A major focus is education and training of students in critical thinking and the scientific method, essential skills for future careers as independent research scientists and important skills for any science-related career. A secondary focus is development of research skills in a broad array of fundamental molecular biological techniques that will prepare students for a variety of research-related careers. Finally, a third goal is development of effective scientific communication skills. The culmination of this goal is presentation of research results at national scientific meetings by students and publication of research papers in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In summary, this project will help train the next generation of research scientists and contribute to the public collection of basic biological knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has contributed several significant findings related to our understanding of how cell division is regulated. The major focus has been to advance our knowledge of how protein degradation and protein modifications like phosphorylation are used to ensure the fidelity of the cell division process using the simple model organism, budding yeast. First, the work revealed a novel mechanism of regulated protein degradation that operates independently of the conventional and well-understood ubiquitin pathway. Second, insight was gained into how protein degradation mediated by one of the master cell cycle regulators is controlled to ensure proper cell division and genome stability, and why this regulation is important. An unexpected finding that arose from this project was the discovery of a unique enzymatic specificity of a phosphatase (an enzyme that removes regulatory phosphate groups from proteins) that is involved in controlling the last stages of cell division. The specificity of this phosphatase has been highly conserved during evolution and provides a plausible mechanism by which cells ensure the proper timing and coordination of late cell cycle events like chromosome segregation and cytokinesis. It also allows the prediction of novel targets of this enzyme that will help reveal its physiological functions in other organisms.

An important outcome from this project is the training and development of young research scientists. Five different graduate students from the Biochemistry graduate program have been supported during the project period and contributed significantly to the research results. Two of these students have successfully completed their Ph.D. now with multiple publications and have moved on to post-doctoral research. In addition, ten undergraduate students acquired intensive research experience working on the funded project, including participants in two different minority research programs on campus. Several of these undergraduates have now moved on to graduate programs at prominent research institutions. The project produced five publications in highly regarded peer-reviewed scientific journals and four presentations at national scientific meetings. Two undergraduate researchers received authorship for their important contributions. In addition to the research findings, the primary investigator's lab also developed mass spectral assays to study the role that phosphorylation and other protein modifications play in physiological processes. These methods, which supported the funded research project, are available to and will benefit other members of the scientific community interested in various aspects of protein regulation. Finally, part of project was featured in a program called ZipTrips developed at Purdue University that produces video programs for middle school science classes across the country.
